creditline: Gift of Mrs. E. C. Gale
department: Chinese, South and Southeast Asian Art
description: Found in a temple near Pondicherry. The figure represents cosmic activity. The significance of the gestures is as follows the drum in the right hand signifies creation; the fire in the upper left hand, destruction; the abaya (fear not) position of the lower right hand, protection; the position of the raised left foot, salvation; the foot placed on the prostrate dwarf, Apasmarapurusa, removal of illusion/ignorance.
text: The god Shiva appears here as Nataraja, or Lord of the Dance. He raises his left foot aloft in a graceful dance pose, while holding destructive fire and a drum in his two upper hands. A now missing ring of fire would have encircled him. This magnificent ceremonial bronze would have been kept in the sacred central sanctum of a temple near to Pondicherry in Tamil Nadu, southeastern India. In 1929, it became the MIAâ€™s first acquisition of South Asian art.
title: Shiva Nataraja (Lord of the Dance)
